issues.description: The problem statement and UML specify a no-argument method checkOrderReady(): void (and instruct students to call checkOrderReady() from orderMeal). In the solution implementation, checkOrderReady is declared with a boolean parameter (checkOrderReady(boolean enableLogging)) and orderMeal calls this.checkOrderReady(true). This is a signature mismatch: the method signature in the solution does not match the method signature described in the problem/UML. Students implementing the method as specified (no parameters) will produce a different API than the solution, and the extra parameter in the solution may confuse learners about the expected method contract.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's checkOrderReady method match the specification by providing a no-argument public void checkOrderReady() method. If internal logging control is desired, either overload checkOrderReady with a private boolean-parameter helper (e.g., private void checkOrderReady(boolean enableLogging)) and keep the public no-arg method that calls it, or remove the parameter and use other means for debug logging. Also update orderMeal to call checkOrderReady() with no arguments so the public API matches the UML and problem description.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML) specifies a no-argument method checkOrderReady(): void on SealSaloon, but the solution implementation exposes checkOrderReady(boolean enableLogging). This changes the public API for the same conceptual operation (checking and serving ready orders) by adding a parameter, which can confuse students who expect to find or implement a no-arg method as described in the exercise. When comparing their implementation to the reference solution or when tests expect the no-arg method, the differing signature forces students to reconcile two different method interfaces for the same concept.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem statement by providing a no-argument public checkOrderReady() method. For example, add a no-arg overload: public void checkOrderReady() { checkOrderReady(true); } — or remove the boolean parameter and implement the logging behavior internally. This preserves the intended API from the exercise while keeping any needed internal logging.
